import { motion, AnimatePresence } from 'framer-motion'; import { useEffect, useState } from 'react'; import './Portfolio.css'; export default function Portfolio() { const [showScrollTop, setShowScrollTop] = useState(false); const [activeModal, setActiveModal] = useState(null); useEffect(() => { const onScroll = () => setShowScrollTop(window.scrollY > 300); window.addEventListener('scroll', onScroll); return () => window.removeEventListener('scroll', onScroll); }, []); const scrollToTop = () => window.scrollTo({ top: 0, behavior: 'smooth' }); return (

Sidney Wood

Sidney.scott.wood@gmail.com

üìç Toronto, ON ¬∑ üìû (647)-542-3540

Visit my LinkedIn

Reflection

Part A ‚Äì Course Reflection

My overall experience in ENG2003 was both surprising and enriching. At first, I expected a traditional writing course focused on grammar and basic formatting, but instead, I encountered a dynamic, professionally relevant curriculum that emphasized clarity, audience awareness, and real-world application. From the beginning, the course challenged me to think critically about how I communicate in various engineering contexts. The assignments pushed me to express technical information in formats that resonate with diverse audiences‚Äîfrom technical reports and infographics to emails and memos. Each format demanded a different style and tone, and I found myself becoming more agile and intentional with my writing choices. One of the most useful pieces of content was the emphasis on the 7 C‚Äôs of communication: clear, concise, concrete, correct, coherent, complete, and courteous. These principles became a lens through which I revised not only my assignments for this course but also my writing in other courses. I especially enjoyed the infographic presentation project. It challenged me to visualize data in ways that are engaging and digestible. The mock interviews and peer feedback exercises were also highlights, as they provided immediate, applicable insights that I will carry into my co-op applications and career. Overall, ENG2003 helped me evolve from a technically capable writer into a more strategic and audience-conscious communicator.

Part B ‚Äì Communication Growth

Before ENG2003, I relied heavily on technical jargon. Now, I communicate more clearly and with purpose. My report writing and presentation skills notably improved, and I‚Äôve grown more confident in tailoring content for diverse audiences.

Showcase

Technical Report (ENG2003)

Why: Clear explanation of complex technical systems.

Development: Improved written communication with visuals.

Comfort Zone: Yes.

Best Work: Yes, due to clarity and organization.

Infographic Presentation (ENG2003)

Why: Combined design and technical data.

Development: Gained skills in simplifying complex content visually.

Comfort Zone: No ‚Äì pushed my visual design skills.

Best Work: Arguably most accessible piece.

Email/Memo Writing (ENG2003)

Why: Practical business writing experience.

Development: Better tone and structure for professional audiences.

Comfort Zone: Yes.

Best Work: Useful, but not my strongest.

Hackathon Pitch (External)

Why: Real-time communication under pressure.

Development: Persuasive speech and synthesis of ideas.

Comfort Zone: Challenging due to live presentation.

Best Work: Strong in delivery and impact.

Passion Projects & Skills

MTG Win Tracker

Tracks Commander deck Elo with Flask and MySQL, deployed on Raspberry Pi. Demonstrates software design, analytics, and backend integration.

GitHub Repo

Skills Snapshot

  • Technical Writing
  • Public Speaking
  • Git, Flask, SQL
  • Collaborative Development

LinkedIn & Contact

You can view more of my projects and connect professionally at linkedin.com/in/sidneywood
